Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

One end of a spring with an unknown spring constant and relaxed length <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"> <mi>L</mi> </math> is attached to a wall. The other end of the spring is attached to a block with mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> that rests on a horizontal surface. There is negligible friction between the block and the surface. The block is pushed to the right and held at rest when the spring is compressed to <math alttext="one half L" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>L</mi></math> as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The block is released, and the block-spring system oscillates such that the maximum speed is <math alttext="v sub max" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math>. Consider the <math alttext="positive x" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi></mpadded></math>-direction to be to the right.

i. Derive an expression for the spring constant <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>.
ii. Derive an expression for the period of oscillation <math alttext="T sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> for the block-spring system.

iii. On the following axes shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, sketch a curve that represents the spring potential energy \(U_s\) of the block-spring system as a function of the position <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> of the block while the block-spring system oscillates.

The block is then brought to rest when the spring is at its relaxed length. A second block of unknown mass moves to the right so that it collides and sticks to the original block. The two blocks slide to the right and momentarily come to rest when the spring is compressed to <math alttext="one half L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>L</mi></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>. The two-blocks-spring system begins to oscillate. All frictional forces are negligible.
(b) The period of the two-block system as it oscillates is <math alttext="T sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. Indicate whether <math alttext="T sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="T sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, the period of oscillation with only one block.
